In the four months since incorporating Opportunity Knocks Communications and working with clients, a major life transition, I've done a great deal of growing and learning along the way. Here's my top five (at least today's top five). 1. Always go to the bathroom when you can. You never know when you might have access or time again. 2. Prioritize exercise. Mental health and physical health are closely tied, we aren't built to sit at desks all day. 3. You never get to go backwards. The time I've been able to spend with family and friends has been irreplaceable and I am so thankful for every second. Recently talking to an aging and ailing friend, he expressed that right now I am choosing to spend time with family and friends, helping with their needs - when you get older, you don't get to choose. inevitably we will lose some and young ones will grow old and set out on their own. 4. Get a puppy. He hasn't arrived yet so this one is tentative at the moment. But I am thrilled to have a companion to share my days starting in mid-February (this will certainly impact rules one through three making them even more important). That's him at the bottom. Yes, I am shamelessly exploiting puppy pictures. 5. Accept what you can't control. The hardest rule to follow yet something that would be on my list any day. Let go of things outside your control and grab onto things within your control, you'll be happier for it - I promise.

Having a clear vision for your life is essential to achieving your goals and living a fulfilling life. Without a vision, you may find yourself wandering aimlessly without direction, feeling unfulfilled or stuck in an unsatisfactory situation. In contrast, having a clear vision for your life provides a roadmap for where you want to go and what you want to achieve. A clear vision helps you identify your priorities and focus on what is truly important to you. It allows you to make decisions that align with your values and goals, and avoid distractions that can lead you off course. Furthermore, a vision provides motivation and inspiration to keep you going, even when faced with obstacles or setbacks. However, developing a vision for your life can be challenging. It requires self-reflection, careful planning, and a willingness to take risks. It may also involve making difficult choices and sacrifices along the way. But the reward of living a life that aligns with your vision is well worth the effort. In conclusion, having a vision for your life is crucial to achieving your goals and living a fulfilling life. It provides clarity, direction, motivation, and inspiration to help you stay on track and achieve your dreams. So take the time to reflect on what's important to you and create a vision that will guide you towards the life you truly desire. So many our company concepts, ideas or strategies have been borrowed from folks I follow on this platform or people I may know personally throughout the world. The conversation around mental health has been such an important topic for our team and one I have had to better understand myself. Thankfully with the help of this platform that information is often front and center from some incredible thought leaders like Adam Weber Kyle Lacy Andrew Huberman Rich Roll Santiago (Santi) Jaramillo Dr. Craig Overmyer and many more! Two years ago we started with the idea to close the business, across every team, every department and every role so that we could: 1. highlight the need to talk about mental health as a company 2. so that we could literally make space for you to focus on yourself, if only for one working shift for one day by closing down the company The feedback from our team has been incredible, they validated how important this day is but they also highlighted something we didn't even think about when we started. When you go on vacation, other people are working and at times it can feel like work piles up while you are gone and then you come back to "dig out" but with our mental health day, when we shut it down and literally discourage working, everyone can collectively breathe a sigh of relief knowing that no one is adding anything to your plate. I'm still learning, we are still making space and we are excited to launch our 2nd mental health day of the year tomorrow. We don't have it all figured out, we have lots to learn but I hope this could encourage someone or other companies to find ways to make space for what belongs by inviting conversations around mental health and like we did two years ago, beg borrow and steal some new ideas. Our entire team California Closets: Indiana | Illinois | Ohio | Kentucky will see you on Monday ğŸ˜ #mentalhealth #mentalhealthawareness #culture #leadership

WE ALL NEED TO BE TUCKED IN â€œClara Ramas, philosopher: "We are all children outdoors wishing to be tucked in". Article published in the newspaper "EL PAÃS". When a person is at their peak in relation to mental health, there is a common aspect that is repeated with more or less intensity: VULNERABILITY. Vulnerability increased and conditioned by two aspects: the impossibility on the part of the individual to act directly (it is not a physical wound), with sometimes partial or not entirely accurate diagnoses, a combination of chemicals that responds to the type and dose when finding the right combination, increasing the feeling of insecurity. The other aspect is the external world (I don't remember the line from the Joker movie again). After COVID, individualism and the loss of values have multiplied, I would say, exponentially. Faced with a vulnerability of such magnitude, people who suffer from it need to be "tucked in" at least during the process. It goes without saying that when that person, once recovered, is "lucky" if they have a profile that can provide a differential value (to avoid entry barriers) to enter an organization it is necessary to "wrap them up" with actions that have hardly any cost (in order of priority: isolation from any toxic environment, flexibility in deadlines and "ad-oc" (recoverable) breaks). As Clara Ramas says, we all need to be tucked in. I remember a (extreme) scene from the movie "saving private Ryan where an American soldier in the middle of the Normandy landings and trying to protect himself screams at his mother scared to death. I personally believe that even the most aggressive executive on Wall Street could collapse if a good enough psychologist struck a chord with him on an emotional issue.

ğŸŒ¿ Exploring the Link Between Psychology and the Environment ğŸŒ¿ This month at Layla we are exploring mental well-being related to the environment. There is a profound connection between our psychological well-being and our external surroundings, including the environment. Here are some key points to understand the connection between psychology and environmental shifts and challenges: â¡ Window of Tolerance: Each of us has a unique threshold for stress and change, known as our window of tolerance. Major events, like climate change, that provoke fear can push us beyond our tolerance window. When this happens, our ability to manage stress significantly decreases, leading to reactions such as anger or emotional shutdown. â¡ Emotional Shutdown: Feeling overwhelmed by major issues such as climate change can cause us to shut down or even avoid the issue. This reaction can stems from a sense of powerlessness, which highlights the impact environmental issues have on our mental health. â¡ Collective Action: Managing mental well-being in the midst of environmental distress involves connecting with others and engaging in impactful environmental initiatives. Our emotional well-being is closely tied to what we do and how we connect with what is important to us. By supporting each other and taking collective action to nurture our environment, we can increase feelings of connection and increase our sense of agency.
